tit.e: Offense and Defense in Omi Province
Offense and Defense in Omi Province
Offense and Defense in Omi Province

sen.j: 近江攻防（おうみこうぼう）は、治承・寿永の乱の中で起きた近江源氏・園城寺僧兵と平家との一連の戦闘。
sen.e: The offense and defense in Omi Province were a series of battles fought between Omi-Genji (the Minamoto clan)/Onjo-ji Temple's armed priests and Heike (the Taira family) during the Jisho-Juei War.
The offense and defense in Omi Province were a series of battles between Omi-Genji (the Minamoto clan) and Onjo-ji Temple's armed priests versus Heike (the Taira family) during the Jisho-Juei War.
The offense and defense in Omi Province were a series of battles between Omi-Genji (the Minamoto clan) and Onjo-ji Temple's armed priests versus Heike (the Taira family) during the Jisho-Juei War.

sen.j: 治承4年（1180年）10月の富士川の戦いで平家が敗れると、同年11月17日尾張国・美濃国の源氏が蜂起する（『玉葉』）。
sen.e: After Heike was defeated in the Battle of Fujigawa in October, 1180, Genji in the Owari Province and the Mino Province rose in revolt on November 17 of the same year ("Gyokuyo," Diary of FUJIWARA no Kanezane).

After Heike was defeated in the Battle of Fujigawa in October, 1180, Genji in the Owari Province and the Mino Province rose in revolt on November 17 of the same year ("Gyokuyo"[Diary of FUJIWARA no Kanezane]).
sen.cmt: 玉葉集の説明を([])にいれました。
sen.e: After Heike was defeated in the Battle of Fujigawa in October, 1180, Genji in the Owari Province and the Mino Province rose in revolt on November 17 of the same year ("Gyokuyo"[Diary of FUJIWARA no Kanezane]).

sen.j: その後11月20日には山本義経・柏木義兼兄弟が挙兵。
sen.e: Afterwards, Yoshitsune YAMAMOTO and Yoshikane KASHIWAGI brothers raised an army on November 20.
Afterwards, Yoshitsune YAMAMOTO and Yoshikane KASHIWAGI brothers raised an army on November 20.

sen.j: 蜂起した近江源氏は北陸地方と平安京を結ぶ物流拠点である琵琶湖を占拠し、北陸から都へ上る年貢を差し押さえた。
sen.e: The uprising Omi-Genji occupied Lake Biwa that was the main artery for distributing goods between the Hokuriku Region and Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto) and seized nengu (land tax) traveling from the Hokuriku Region to Heian-kyo.

The uprising Omi-Genji occupied Lake Biwa that was the main artery for distributing goods between the Hokuriku Region and Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto) and seized nengu (land tax) on the way from the Hokuriku Region to Heian-kyo.
sen.cmt: 上るの訳をtravelling からon the way に変更しました（運ばれる途中と解釈して）
sen.e: The uprising Omi-Genji occupied Lake Biwa that was the main artery for distributing goods between the Hokuriku Region and Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto) and seized nengu (land tax) on the way from the Hokuriku Region to Heian-kyo.

sen.j: 園城寺の僧兵達も近江源氏と手を結び、その連合軍は一時平安京を占拠する勢いを見せる。
sen.e: The armed priests of Onjo-ji Temple also allied with Omi-Genji and the allied forces' power was strong enough to occupy Heian-kyo at one point.

sen.j: また、東国の甲斐源氏とも連絡をとっていたようで、近江源氏が武田信義と連絡をとっていたらしいことが『玉葉』に記載されている。
sen.e: It is likely that Omi-Genji was in contact with Kai-Genji in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region); it is written in "Gyokuyo" that Omi-Genji was probably contacting Nobuyoshi TAKEDA.

It is assumed that Omi-Genji was in contact with Kai-Genji in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region), as "Gyokuyo" described that Omi-Genji was probably contacting Nobuyoshi TAKEDA.
sen.cmt: likely → assumedセミコロンではなくasで結び、"Gyokuyo"以下を変更しました。
sen.e: It is assumed that Omi-Genji was in contact with Kai-Genji in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region), as "Gyokuyo" described that Omi-Genji was probably contacting Nobuyoshi TAKEDA.

sen.j: また同書には、この反乱に若狭国の在庁官人 が同意の動きをとっていたことも見え、翌年以降活発化する北陸の反乱勢力の蜂起の萌芽が見られる。
sen.e: It is also written in "Gyokuyo" that Zaichokanjin in the Wakasa Province was likely in support of the uprising and it is possible to see the germination of the increase in the Hokuriku's uprising power.

It is also written in "Gyokuyo" that Zaichokanjin (local district officials) in the Wakasa Province was likely in support of the uprising, so the sign of the Hokuriku's uprisings to increase was recognized.
sen.cmt: 用語に在庁官人 Zaichokanjinとありますが、英語での説明をつけないと意味不明だと考え、(local district officials)を挿入しましたgermination 主に植物の発芽に使われる単語のため、萌芽の訳をsignにしました。
sen.e: It is also written in "Gyokuyo" that Zaichokanjin (local district officials) in the Wakasa Province was likely in support of the uprising, so the sign of the Hokuriku's uprisings to increase was recognized.

sen.j: 一方畿内近辺の反乱勢力の蜂起に対して平家は反撃に転じる。
sen.e: Meanwhile, Heike went on the counteroffensive by raising the uprising power in the Kinai region (the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto).
Meanwhile, Heike went on the counteroffensive by raising the uprising power in the Kinai region (the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto).

sen.j: 福原京に都を遷していた朝廷は、11月21日平安京への還都を決定。
sen.e: The Imperial Court decided to change the capital which had been located in Fukuhara-kyo to Heian-kyo on November 21.
The Imperial Court decided to change the capital which had been located in Fukuhara-kyo to Heian-kyo on November 21.

sen.j: 26日には平清盛が平安京に戻る。
sen.e: TAIRA no Kiyomori returned to Heian-kyo on the 26th.
TAIRA no Kiyomori returned to Heian-kyo on the 26th.

sen.j: 続いて高倉天皇から近江寺社勢力に対して謀反人追討の院宣が発せられる。
sen.e: Then, Emperor Takakura issued inzen (a decree from the retired Emperor) which declared the hunting down and killing the rebels against Omi Temple's troops.
Then, Emperor Takakura issued inzen (a decree from the retired Emperor) which declared the hunting down and killing of the rebels against Omi Temple's troops.

sen.e: Then, Emperor Takakura issued inzen (a decree from the retired Emperor) which declared the hunting down and killing of the rebels against Omi Temple's troops.

sen.j: 12月1日平家家人平家継が近江源氏に攻撃を開始し、2日には平知盛が追討に向かった。
sen.e: TAIRA no Ietsugu, Heike's Kenin (a retainer), started an attack on December 1 and TAIRA no Tomonori headed for the battle for an additional attack on 2nd.
TAIRA no Ietsugu, Heike's Kenin (a retainer), started an attack against Omi Genji on December 1 and TAIRA no Tomonori headed for the battle for an additional attack on 2nd.
sen.cmt: 近江源氏 訳抜けに対応しました。
sen.e: TAIRA no Ietsugu, Heike's Kenin (a retainer), started an attack against Omi Genji on December 1 and TAIRA no Tomonori headed for the battle for an additional attack on 2nd.

sen.j: 6日に行なわれた戦闘では知盛らによって近江源氏が打ち破られた。
sen.e: Tomomori and others defeated Omi-Genji in the battle took place on 6th.
Tomomori and others defeated Omi-Genji in the battle that took place on 6th.
Tomomori and others defeated Omi-Genji in the battle that took place on 6th.

sen.j: この戦に敗れた兵の多くは美濃へ逃れて抵抗を続けることになる。
sen.e: Many soldiers defeated in this battle fled to the Mino Province and kept up the resistance.
Many soldiers defeated in this battle fled to the Mino Province and kept up the resistance.
Many soldiers defeated in this battle fled to the Mino Province and kept up the resistance.

sen.j: 平家は園城寺内の反乱軍に同意した僧兵たちにも攻撃を加え、その結果園城寺の一部が炎上する。
sen.e: Heike attacked the armed priests who agreed to support the rebel troops in Onjo-ji Temple; as a result, a part of Onjo-ji Temple blazed up.
Heike attacked the armed priests who agreed to support the rebel troops in Onjo-ji Temple; as a result, a part of Onjo-ji Temple blazed up.
Heike attacked the armed priests who agreed to support the rebel troops in Onjo-ji Temple; as a result, a part of Onjo-ji Temple blazed up.

sen.j: 12月13日には近江において最後まで抵抗を続け馬渕城にたてこもって山本義経が追い落とされる（『玉葉』）。
sen.e: Omi-Genji kept up the resistance in the Omi Province on around December 24 by shutting themselves up in the Mabuchi Castle but Yoshitsune YAMAMOTO was forced to flee ("Gyokuyo").
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処主語をはっきり書いていないので、Omi-Genjiとしました。
sen.e: On December 24 Yoshitsune YAMAMOTO, who kept up the resistance in the Omi Province and shut himself up in Mabuchi-jo Castle, was finally forced to flee ("Gyokuyo").
sen.cmt: 原文の「たてこもって」は「たてこもっていた」の間違いだと考えられます。(1180年の出来事より）。抵抗を続け、たてこもっていたの主語は山本義経だと考え文章を変更しました。
sen.e: On December 24 Yoshitsune YAMAMOTO, who kept up the resistance in the Omi Province and shut himself up in Mabuchi-jo Castle, was finally forced to flee ("Gyokuyo").

sen.j: しかし、12月24日頃山本城にこもって抵抗を続けていることが確認されている（『玉葉』）。
sen.e: However, it is confirmed that Yoshitsune YAMAMOTO kept up the resistance by shutting himself up in Yamamoto Castle on around December 24 ("Gyokuyo").

sen.e: However, it is confirmed that Yoshitsune YAMAMOTO kept up the resistance and shut himself up in Yamamoto-jo Castle around December 24 ("Gyokuyo").

sen.e: However, it is confirmed that Yoshitsune YAMAMOTO kept up the resistance and shut himself up in Yamamoto-jo Castle around December 24 ("Gyokuyo").

sen.j: その後山本義経は1183年の源義仲軍の上洛に同行することになる。
sen.e: Afterwards, Yoshitsune YAMAMOTO came to accompany MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka's army to attack Heian-kyo in 1183.
Afterwards, Yoshitsune YAMAMOTO accompanied MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka's army to attack Heian-kyo in 1183.

sen.j: 12月には近江の攻防が終息に向かうが、奈良勢力の活動が活発化し尾張美濃の源氏は翌年まで反乱活動を続けることになる。
sen.e: The offense and defense in the Omi Province came near the end in December; however, the Nara troops' revel activity gained momentum and Genji in the Owari and Mino Province kept up the rebellion until next year.
The offense and defense in the Omi Province came near the end in December; the revel activity gained momentum in Nara and Genji in the Owari and Mino Provinces kept up the rebellion until next year.
